conclusion: The problem involves finding the average velocity and average speed of a particle moving along two semicircular arcs with a radius of 1 meter, taking 5 seconds.

The images show a particle moving along a path from point A to point C, consisting of two semicircular arcs: the first semicircle from A to B (above the horizontal line) and the second semicircle from B to C (below the horizontal line). Each semicircle has a radius of 1 meter, and the total time taken is 5 seconds.
Displacement is the straight-line distance from start to finish (from A to C).

From the diagram, points A, B, and C all lie on the same horizontal line. If A is at the origin, B is 2 meters from A (diameter of the first semicircle), and C is 4 meters from A (2m from A to B plus 2m from B to C).
The displacement is 4 meters in the eastward direction.
The distance traveled is the total length of the path, which consists of two semicircles.
The length of a semicircle is π × radius, so the length of each semicircle is π × 1m = π meters.
The total distance traveled is π + π = 2π meters ≈ 6.28 meters.
Average velocity is the displacement divided by the time taken: Average velocity = Displacement / Time = 4 m / 5 s = 0.8 m/s eastward.
Average speed is the total distance traveled divided by the time taken: Average speed = Distance / Time = 2π m / 5 s = 2π/5 m/s ≈ 1.257 m/s.
The final answer is: Average velocity = 0.8 m/s eastward, Average speed = 2π/5 m/s ≈ 1.257 m/s.

Average velocity is a vector quantity that depends on the displacement (straight-line distance from A to C), while average speed is a scalar quantity that depends on the total distance traveled along the curved path.
